description: Timeline 400 B.C.,Greece. The foundation has been laid for a new temple. Two "architects" attempt to form a line of 3 constructions which are topped by the same type of playing piece. Using the Corinthian Column capitals, columns and bases as the playing pieces, an architect may add a new piece to the game, stack a piece on top of another, or move a piece. Competitive strategy skills will cast the winner’s name in stone!

From the publisher's website:
Swearword memo-game.

Friesen-Torn is a wild kind of regatta, where 3-6 players are chasing each other with their small sail boats. In the best pirate's tradition, the opponents' boats are rammed in order to get winning points. Friesen-Torn is like bumper cars in the sea. Players steer their boats by special sailing cards.

Here's a description of the game from Spielbox:

This new publisher is presenting its first game: Tenakee. Under the title ‘Coco-Nut’, Michael Feldkotter had submitted this game as part of the SAZ competition for game authors at last year’s Essen fair. Alan R. Moon had run the competition and fronted the prize money; 9 authors with a total of 16 prototypes entered. This game won first prize.

The great totem pole competition is being held among the Tenakee Indians. Those taking part want to show off the most beautiful and valuable totem poles. But the poles are only scored when it gets a point, so that the Indians like to annoy each other by climbing up and putting points on poles. At the same time, the squaws are using the event to search for a man. Which carver is brave enough to climb the high totem poles?

Manufacturer's Description
Fart
Flatulent fun with your CD player!

Fart is the sound-sational game of rip-roaring fun that will challenge even straight-laced Aunt Grace to keep a straight face!

An instant source of laughter, Fart is the hilarious game in which you race to be the first to play out of cards whilst accompanied by a fast 'n' frantic Fart-chorus!

Every now and then an unrealistically enormous explosion will let rip forcing you to change direction, pick up penalty cards or 'Pass the Wind' to your neighbor!

Wild hilarity at the press of a button, Fart is the side-splitting game that helps you to unwind and release a little pressure!

Box Contents

99 Track Fart Effect CD
Score Pad + Rule Book
Fart Game Cards

Each player receives a double sided card which is keyed so that a question on one card requires an answer on the card of another player. This high-interest activity allows players to become familiar with the capitals and numerous geographic characteristics of all 50 states. Grades 6-12

Players use these 50, four-sided domino game to match the capitals, time zones, and geographic regions of the 50 United States. Each of the four different categories have different point values. Strategic placement achieves high scores! 1-4 players. Grades 4-8
Play checkers and enjoy improving addition and subtraction skills. This fun and fast paced game may be played by two individuals or two teams with similar or different learning ability. Grades 2-6

Jungle Bungle is a truly new kind of game that's out and out fun. With its talking dice, lucky dip bag and exciting game play it is a must for kids of all ages. Players are out to get a full set of snaps of the wild jungle animals prowling the board. Each turn the dice, growls, trumpets, roars, laughs or tells you what to do.

Players learn how to build words using prefixes and base words. The base words are located within the game board squares, and the prefixes are listed on the spinner. Students spin and move to the first space where that prefix can be used with a base word to form a word. 245 words can be formed. 2-4 players. Grades 4-8

Over 400 problems for each of the four basic math operations are included in this exciting fractions game. Competition in ten popular Olympics events are used to motivate players. For example, the javelin, discus, shot-put, pole vault, and many more activities allow students to earn points towards winning a gold, silver, or bronze medal. For 2-4 players and a referee.

Players will begin to understand the problem solving details that go into having a party as they play this game. Included are activities that use addition and subtraction of time, money, and liquid measurement. For example: 4 cups of punch equal one quart. How many cups of punch equal one gallon? The time is 1:00p.m. and the party starts in 15 minutes. What time does the party start? 2-4 players Grades 2-6

Here's an action packed board game designed to meet a variety of educational needs while tapping into America's favorite pastime... Baseball! As players build their own teams, they use their own baseball cards or the baseball cards included in the game to answer problem solving questions. Included are integrated reading, math, and geography skills covering time zones, states and capitals, major league cities, rivers, lakes, and oceans. Lots of baseball trivia is included. There are five levels of difficulty, allowing players of different ability levels to play together. 2-4 players or teams. Grades 2-12

45 durable dominoes are included in this challenging game. It may be played at three levels of difficulty, covering hours, half hours, and quarter hours using clock faces, digital time, and written time. 1-4 players. Grades 2-6

Here's a great, competitive, fun-filled game. Each player chooses a colored pawn and follows the track around the board by spinning and moving to a specific number in either the ones, tens, hundreds and thousands place. The winner is decided by the first player who makes it once around the board and follows their colored alley to the center of the board. Grades 1-4

Here's a great, competitive, fun-filled game. Each player chooses a colored pawn and follows the track around the board by spinning and moving to a specific number in the thousand, millions, up to the hundred millions place. The winner is decided by the first player who makes it once around the board and follows their colored alley to the center of the board.

This started life as a computer game by Ingo Althöfer and has been worked into a board game by Reinhold Wittig. The board is in the shape of Easter Island (Rapa Nui) and has 45 spaces. Each player has 2 pieces which are placed on the board. On a turn a piece is moved to an adjacent empty space and a wooden die-holder is then put in the place just moved from. A die is then rolled and put in the holder. After the first 9 moves, each turn also has a second element. This is to remove an empty holder from the board or to roll a die and remove a die from the board with the same number (thus leaving an empty holder). The aim is to be the last player to be able to move.
You need to be able to corner off an area for yourself and also to be in positions where removal of dice will benefit your future movement.

This is a collection of 12 games playable with the same components released to commemorate the 150th anniversary of Gauss' death. The games are mainly 2 player. They use a set of wooden blocks which come in lengths of 1 to 6. A die is used in many of them to determine the length of the piece to be placed. There are variants on connecting-sides-of-the-board, placement-within-a-limited-space, moving- across-the-board, blocking and capturing games. 8 are adult games, 4 children's games. There are also an additional 2 adult games by Peter Lewe.

In the center of the board, there are wobble puddings in a clearing. Players roll a die and move their 'little monster' to collect them and bring them back to their home. But the puddings are guarded by a dragon, which may be moved when the players roll its symbol. Players can be send home like in pachisi, with the capturing player also capturing the pudding.

The game ends when all 10 puddings are distributed. They have 1-3 points on the bottom side, and the player with the highest total wins.

In Henne Berta (Hen Berta in English) the player feeds a hen with grain and in return gathers eggs to a little basket. The first player that gets 3 eggs to basket is the winner. The game contains a wooden board, large wooden pieces and little baskets for every player.

How long did John Glenn orbit the earth? This and many more curious questions are included in this fun-filled game. History, math, problem solving, and trivia are incorporated into three levels of difficulty so that students at different ability levels can be challenged as they play together. 2-4 Players Grade 3-8

Place Search is a great activity in a four-sided domino format. Players match words with their corresponding numerals. Two levels of difficulty cover numbers through the hundred millions place. 1-4 players. Grades 3-12
This game contains 45 dominoes and five game ideas using halves, thirds, fourths, fifths, sixths, and eighths. It's great for home use or learning centers.

"Jon Compton's tactical hex and counter game of WWII combat. This set focuses on Germany versus Poland at the start of the war."

Each hex on the map represents an area approximately 100 yards across. Each playing piece represents about 40-60 men (a platoon) or half a dozen vehicles or towed weapons . . . For ease of play, the game scales are approximated. Time is also abstracted, thus turns represent several minutes.

The FOXHOLE system is simple to learn and fast playing that focuses on the invasion of Poland. Its a good diversion from the more heavy fair of historical board-wargaming.

FOXHOLE SET 2 includes:
-Ten new scenarios, six exclusively with this set, and four incorporating elements from Set 1.
-Twenty-four unit cards
-Over one hundred playing pieces -Tactical Battles Map A - and One rule book

This game is played on a hex board, you have 3 Figures, the first (King) can move only 1 step (if you lose that piece you are out of the game), the second piece can move 2 step and the third can move 3 step. When you move on a hex a stone fall, so the hex is no more usable. When you must move one figure on an empty hex, the first time you can turn over the figure, the second time the figure goes out of the game. If is the King all your figures go out. The last player on the board is the winner.

It's the first game of a trilogy of two-player Napoleonic campaign games.
Napoleon's Italian campaigns take place during the time of Napoleon's campaigns from 1796 through 1800 in Italy.
The game contains the maps, 252 counters, charts and tables

Picdoku is a brand new pictorial version of the Sudoku craze that has gripped us all! It can be played individually or competitively by 2 players or teams. Each game includes 182 sturdy re-usable tokens and 30 double-sided playing boards so that 60 different games can be played again and again.

Santiago 1898: Final del Imperio is a simulation of the campaign of Santiago de Cuba during the Spanish - American War.

One A3 sized map, 200 cut and paste counters.
Battle of Lake Trasimene (217 BC) during the Second Punic war.

The Battle of Adua, 1896: Italy against the Abyssinians. 
"Alea Iacta Est" Italian wargaming magazine, issue 4.

Uses the same game system as Invasion of Italy, Red Parachutes and Red Steel. As far as we know, this is the first detailed treatment of the battles that, at last, stopped Erwin Rommel’s attempts to take the British position in the Nile delta. They also established Bernard Montgomery as the British general finally able to defeat the "Desert Fox."

Following the fall of Tobruk in May 1942, the Commonwealth forces in the desert struggled to reach the last real defensive position before Alexandria and halt what seemed to be an unstoppable Afrika Korps. At battalion and company level, four turns a day and 2 kilometers per hex, this game includes German, Italian, Indian, British, South African, New Zealand, Australian, Free French and Greek units that fought in the desperate struggle.

Scenarios include the Australian and South African spoiling attack in mid-July, the late June battle for the Mersa Matruh position where slow response almost cost the Commonwealth the bulk of the New Zealand Division, the first Axis attack on the Alamein line in early July, the last Axis attack to break the Allied line at Alam el Halfa at the end of August, Operation LIGHTFOOT: the Eighth Army’s attack against the Axis line in late October and the massive campaign from the end of June to the beginning of November 1942.

Four full-sized maps and 2,100 game pieces.

From the box:
"A game of Maine trivia suitable for natives and people from away."

Players start in Kittery (Southern Maine). Counties in Maine represent different categories. As players roll and move around the board, they must collect cards at each county seat. Players then race to Fort Kent (Northern Maine) to win the game.

Three levels of difficulty are included in this fast-paced tic-tac-toe styled game. Three game cards are included and players match antonyms from their playing card, to base words found on the spinner. The first person to form a line of antonyms on the board wins the game.

This is a very large book (900 pages) explaining rules to all kinds of games.  The first 300 pages are dedicated solely to card games.  The book then moves on to traditional board and dice games such as checkers, backgammon, and craps.  There are many word and guessing games.  Outdoor activities are also listed, including races, snow or water games, lawn games, and full-blown sports.

Ideas for adults' get-togethers include quick-thinking contests and even dancing games.  The book details countless games for children, suitable for everyday play or social events such as birthday parties.  Some of the party games are geared toward specific holidays.

This huge volume devotes one little paragraph to branded games such as Monopoly, Pit, and Flinch.  It only mentions that they exist, and require special equipment, which is purchased along with the rules.

Although you'll find very familiar entries such as bridge, marbles, and baseball, many of the games are less known, or a variation on a more familiar idea.  Some of the names are intriguing in their own right.  Here's a sampling of names of the many games to learn:

Misery Nap
Bierspiel
Anti-nudist
Hearts of Lettuce
Skeegee-Weegee
The G Man Never Takes His Ease
Literary Salad
Strawberries Without Cream
Schnozzle Race

Players learn how to build words using suffixes and base words. The base words are located within the gameboard squares, and the suffixes are listed on the spinner. Students spin and move to the first space where that suffix can be used with a base word to form a word. 245 words can be formed.

From the back cover:

"The alternative games in this booklet are all designed to be played with standard equipment. They offer exciting new dimensions to games played on or with draught boards, cards, dominoes etc., helping to eliminate the constant financial burden of purchasing expensive and often short-lived new games.

The games in Alternative Games for Those Who Like a Challenge are based on popular games that have been modified so they are even more competitive and exciting.
At the same time, they are easy to learn if you already know the standard edition, providing hours of inexpensive entertainment, making this booklet desirable for most game lovers.

Other books designed by Tony Crow are:
Alternative Games for the Family and
Alternative Games for the Studious"

This book contains rules for modified card games, draught board games, Scrabble games and billiard table games.

"Who was blinded on the road to Damascus?" "Who asked to be tried in Rome?" Players answer these and other questions from the book of Acts as they match these four-sided dominoes. There are two complete sets of dominoes with one set emphasizing people, and the other set emphasizing places. Scriptural references and an answer key is included. 2-4 players. Ages 10 and up

Bible Search is a game of advance and block whose moves are generated by correctly answering the questions, of which there are 3 categories (Beginner, Intermediate and Advanced) in each of 2 sources, the Old Testament and the New Testament.  Correctly answering a question generates 2 choices, a move to advance your pawn 1 space, or a block option which, if successful, allows you to block your opponent(s) progress, or chance missing a turn, advancing 2 spaces or moving back 2 if question incorrectly answered or advancing 1 space or moving back 2 if question incorrectly answered.

From demo packet:

Capes & Cowls: Adventures in Wyrd City. It's super fun in 3 easy steps:


        1. Recruit a team of heroes. 
        2. Send them into battle. 
        3. Clobber till content.


Wyrd City—where conflict lies in wait around every corner and the shadows are acrawl with mystery and adventure, where liberty wanes, government waxes, and a chosen few don capes and cowls to take their stand in a world gone Wyrd....

Capes & Cowls: The Superhero Board Game features 32 original Heroes (and/or villains, depending on your perspective) and several Crews of secondary characters, including Freedom Patrols, Liberty Bots, Diabloids, Arachnidrones, Darklings, thugs, and zombies. Each Hero is defined by personalized stats (Attack, Defense, Speed, and Vigor) and 3 unique Powers, while each Crew is defined by personalized stats and 1 unique Power. Altogether, Capes & Cowls provides over 75 characters with over 100 Powers.
    
Capes & Cowls is played on a unique Battleboard whose color- and number-coded spaces influence character abilities, modify power levels, and place strong emphasis on strategic and tactical play. Though certain game situations do require a roll of the Battle Die, skillful players will find themselves seldom relying on luck to determine the outcome of an action. In short, the player who recruits and manages his team of Heroes most wisely will nearly always prove the victor.

Capes & Cowls offers the following 3 modes of play:

1. Basic: In the Basic Game, each player recruits a team of 2 or 3 Heroes, deploys the team to the Battleboard, and dukes it out with his opponent’s team for a predetermined number of rounds. The victory goes to the player with the most Heroes left on the Battleboard at the end of the game.

2. Standard: The Standard Game allows each player to recruit a team of 4 or 5 Heroes, and introduces Scene Features such as Rooftops, Walls, and Trees, as well as Objects such as Boulders, Cars, and Mailboxes. These elements enrich the Battleboard environment and call for keener strategies and sharper tactics. The victory, as in the Basic Game, goes to the player with the most Heroes left on the Battleboard at the end of the game.

3. Adventure: The Adventure Game requires the players to select an Adventure from the Adventure Book. Each Adventure includes a full-color map for Battleboard setup, instructions for team recruitment, and special rules for playing the chosen Adventure, including team-specific goals and victory conditions. This mode of play incorporates Crew characters, special items, and plot devices that further define the Wyrd City universe and its colorful assortment of costumed denizens. The victory in an Adventure Game goes to the player whose team succeeds in fulfilling the predetermined goal of the Adventure.

In addition to the above modes of play, Capes & Cowls also allows for solitaire and multiplayer variations.

Wyrd City—where the “good guys” are bad, the “bad guys” are you, and the dress code is decidedly unusual.

Capes & Cowls: The Superhero Board Game! Let the battle begin!

Corsair Leader is based on the Hornet Leader II core game, but with some significant changes.  The game focuses on the Marine F4U Corsairs in the Pacific. The 2 campaigns cover the Solomon Islands campaign that lasted from late 1942 to early 1944.

Also, the aircraft under your command center on the Corsair, but you also get to decide if you want to include Dauntlesses, B-25s, and B-17s as part of your group. Each aircraft has its own advantages and disadvantages. For example, the B-17s carry a lot of bombs and are hard to shoot down, but they are terrible versus naval targets and only moderately accurate against all but the largest of land targets.

The game also goes more in-depth on the tactical options you have while over target. Each turn, each aircraft can become "Offensive" which gives it an attack bonus, but also makes it easier to be attacked when it gets shot at. Likewise, aircraft can be "Defensive" which penalizes their own attacks and makes them harder to hit. "Slow" pilots can "Rush" their attack at a penalty and attack during the Fast pilot step, and "Fast" pilots can Wait and get a bonus if they attack during the Slow pilot step.

Like the other games in the "Leader" series, Corsair Leader is a solitaire game.

The game is published in both PDF and Vassal versions.

Other Leader series games by Dan Verssen

Scale is 240 yards per hex and each unit is a battalion or regiment.  There are also some German companies for the front trenches.  There are two 13x19" maps with over 200 counters. There are two rules books - standard rules that are 5 pages and Messines:1917 rules that run another 4 pages.  There are two scenarios - first day and campaign. Artillery is the centerpiece of the game with four different types of bombardment (saturation,  standard, intermittent, and gas) possible.  There are three types of guns - field, medium, and heavy with each best suited to certain roles.  For Messines the addition of mines makes initial set up and play a real chess match.  The key to victory is correct deployment and effective use of reserves.  For the Allies, one of the key decisions is how much to bombard.  It is very effective but it also destroys the drainage systems of the area and leads to a quagmire that with eliminated possibilities.  For the German player, commitment of reserves is the key.  He has to guess correctly at the main points of attack by the British player before they have sufficiently evolved to make the attack plan apparent.

Good stewardship of time, ability, and money is an important part of life. This exciting game introduces children to the principles of good stewardship. As players move around the game board they earn money for a variety of tasks. They learn to put money in savings and in the church offering. There are opportunities to spend money, recycle and do community service projects. A scripture memory component is also included. For 2-4 players. Ages 6 - 12

A multi-level maths game to support the national numeracy strategy in an entertaining way. Trilemma tests the times tables and other mathematical functions non-sequentially. This challenging game of chance and skill can be played in a mixed age group with different players choosing different levels within the same game.

Here's a great card game for visual learners! Players match equivalent fractions or find sums of "ONE." Included are cards representing halves, thirds, fourths, sixths, and eighths. Each card pictures a fraction, gives the number word, and shows its corresponding numeral.
Here's a great way to learn about percentages using dominoes! It's a great game for individuals, or small groups in a learning center.

Battle of the Monsters is a set of several games that can be played using the trading cards included in the Weird n' Wild Creatures collectors set. Weird n' Wild Creatures is a set of colorful data cards covering monsters of nature and mythology. The creatures on the data cards are also depicted on trading cards which list values for attack, defense, and life, which are used to play the Battle of the Monsters games. Some cards also list special powers. The games that can be played with the cards range from the very simple (a war variant where cards and drawn and attack values are compared) to the strategic.

How could that have happened? Black Stories are fiddly, morbid and mysterious riddles for teenagers and adults. The players try to reconstruct the crime by asking, guessing and fiddling about. Only yes/no answers are allowed. A spooky card game just right for any party.
Here's a basic subtraction activity using a competitive tic-tac-toe format. Three levels of difficulty cover subtraction problems from 1 to 20. Great for home use or in learning centers.
Here's a basic division activity using a competitive tic-tac-toe format. Three levels of difficulty cover basic division problems. Great for home use or in learning centers.

A nautical quiz game where navigators must sail the seas and answer questions about ecology and the rules of the sea.

Themed on the show of the same name on France 3.
